bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, February 22, 1947

div1.p: Kean is upset over Ames' claim that he had experimental yellow fever, which he knows is incorrect.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, February 22, 1947
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
22 Feb. 1947
My dear Truby
div1.p:
Isnt it surprizing how the
days slip by, when each day is much
like the one before, and one feels well
and spends the days reading. Your
very nice letter has been on my desk
for a month or more, and I dont think
I have yet answered it. But I will
do so and put on an air mail stamp
so that spring will not catch me with
a mid-winter letter from so good a friend
still unanswered. I have just been talking
to Mrs Siler over the phone about the fine
recovery that our friend ‘Dusty’ has made
after giving us a great scare. He had a
prostate operation early in this month.
2-
It was not malignant, thank God, but
he had a phlebitis of the left iliac vein
and they had to tie off the vein and turn
out the clot. Then he had a pneumonia
and had to live under an oxygen tent
for a week or more. He was very ill but
all of a sudden, he began to get better and
is now sitting up part of each day.
We have just had the biggest snow in
five years, over Va. Md & up to New England
and it is now cold with a bitter west
wind so the city is now slowly digging
itself out. We will probably have a late
spring this year, as we had early springs last
year and in 1945. As this winter is the
first when R. R. transportation has approach-
ed normal almost every one I know
has gone to Florida and they will have
3
spent their money and be wanting to come home
long before spring comes to us.

It was a great pleasure to hear of Jack's
visit to you and of how will Elizabeth
is coming on with her work.

Also to hear of your fine visit from Col Hench
which he also wrote me of. I had a
big envelope from him today with letters
about Ames from a Dr. Berry who thinks
Ames had a case of experimental yellow
fever - which is of course all tommy-rot.
I think that Col. Hench has now got the
whole story and he should get to work on
his magnum opus without wasting pre-
cious time on fake heroes who try to
climb on the band wagon after the battle
was over. You are much mistaken if
C2
B5
you think that Col. Hench ever thought for
a moment that you were a Dr. Victor Heiser
He is too shrewd a judge of human nature
ever to have a doubt of your story and
he admires your book as much as I do.
But he goes over the old ground again
and again in his efforts to get additional
facts that we may have over looked or
forgotten. I tell him that I am a squeezed
orange and he cannot get anything
more out of me. You know Hench came
all the way from Rochester, Minn. to Wash.
to attend the Nov. meeting of the Walter Reed
memo. Assn. and I think enjoyed it.
I will look forward with much pleasure
to seeing you in May when you come east
and will save a bottle of bottled-in-bond
to drink to your health. Cordial regards to
Madame Bonnie and Elizabeth.
